content.description: This route is awesome!   Start by climbing up the left side of the cave.  At the 2nd bolt, head left.  (The route branching out right over the cave is Flesh and Blood, 5.13a.)  The 3rd bolt is hidden in a hueco.   Climb up through several huecos using kneebars to reach a layback flake.  Pull up and into a stance in a left facing corner (crux).   Make a few more moves to reach an overhang with a great rest.  From here, pull the overhand and continue up into an alcove.   Exit the alcove on the right using sharp holds to the chains.  When lowering, it's easiest to lower down the the hand line and just climb back up.   The easiest way back to the ground is to lower all the way down, and then belay your belayer back down to the ground.
content.location: Locate the Arch and then hike right and uphill along the cliff and locate a hand line.  Climb up the hand line into an alcove and set up shop.   White Soul Power starts on the right most line of bolts directly above the hand line.

content.description: Pull a few big moves down low between the huge pods on the right side of the cave. Make a tricky exit move into the grey streak above. Techy climbing on sharp rock brings you to the anchor.
content.location: Scramble into the large cave using a handline. Look for the huge pods on the right side. There is a belay bolt.

content.description:
Start up the great pockets of 'One Taste' but veer left.  A long, bouldery sequence on small pockets and crimps gets you to a great rest in the huge pod.  Steep climbing in the pod leads to a final boulder problem exiting the pod to gain the chains.  Tall folks will be able to reach the final jug, shorties will need to use some small intermediates and/or get a little dynamic.  Great finish!

This route is not as clean as 'One Taste' but climbs nearly as well.  Probably a touch easier given the no hands rest in the middle.

Bring some quicklinks, chain, or something to extend and fix the hilarious anchor situation that existed Nov. 2018.  I unfortunately had none of those things.
content.location: Immediately right of the huge choss/poo chimney

content.description: Climb Soul Train to the break where the rock turns gold and gets steeper.    Take the left line of bolts with gray hangers.   The first few holds are reinforced with epoxy.     Although it looks ugly up close, this line climbs quite nicely.   The features appear to be all natural, its just that the FA decided to reinforce them and probably for good reason.

A fun, long line with several somewhat steeper sections to overcome on the way up. Pockets abound, along with positive edges. In one or two steeper locations just a bit of less-than-totally straightforward movement is required.

After the eleventh bolt, head up and right a bit through a scoop to the final three bolts and the anchors.
content.location:
The left line of the two routes located between the two large, dead, fire-blacked trees. You may think that this is

Righteous Indignation

, but look  in the Goss guidebook and you'll note that

Righteous Indignation

is a line to the left of the large-ish green tree in the photo (which tree is now the left, or downhill, blackened crisp).

(This line and the line to its right aren't in the guidebook.)

content.description: Slab to gently overhanging streaked face that offers fun, pumpy climbing on pockets
content.location: Between Arch Enemy and Lost Soul.  Start in the big scoop.

content.description: A long route immediately left of Arch Rival.  Slabby start to a gently overhanging crux between the 6th and 7th bolts, finishing on chains that are slightly too left for the route (doesn't matter, still a great line).
content.protection: Don't remember the exact draw count, but plan on at least 12 plus 2 for the chains.  Bring 15 to be safe.

content.description: Start on Secrets and Lies.  Get a full shake out at the anchors but continue on past thin, technical terrain to the top set of anchors.
content.location: Same start as Secrets and Lies.

content.description:
A steadily-steepening route with a pumpy, reachy crux on less-than-totally-positive holds.

Start up a dirty, crumbling alcove to the first bolt, wondering if the edges you are stepping on in order to clip the first bolt will crumble into oblivion. Continue up and right  through three more bolts using large pockets to an enormous, deep pocket (it'll swallow most of your arm).

The fifth bolt and the crux lurk above; figure out how to get to more positive territory with initially inobvious holds and poor feet.

Through the crux, breathe a sigh of relief while trying to figure out the final moves to the anchors.

The Goss guidebook reports that continuing above the rap anchors to another set of anchors clocks in at .12d.
content.location:
On the left side of the right alcove of

The Arch Wall

, the first bolt is located  above a loose, dark brown alcove at what appears at first glance to be an uncomfortably high level. The subsequent bolts trend up and right.

content.description: This fun moderate climbs a low angle clean slab for ~100ft to a bulge crux before the anchor. A good lead for the moderate climber.
content.location: The leftmost slab route on the left of the wall

content.description:
Start up a shallow trough next to some vegetation to the first bolt. Continue up lower angle, good quality rock to a mild bulge that requires a little thinking to get through.

After the bulge cruise to the top.
content.location:
Near the left side of

The Arch Wall

just before the slight corner that delineates the left side of

Ren and Stimpy

.

More-or-less directly behind the right (while facing the wall) of the two largish, burnt trees.

content.description: Climb the first five bolts on White Soul Power, then traverse right to finish on Flesh and Blood's anchor.
content.location: Near the apex of the slope, find a hand line 25' below a steep alcove.  Climb up the easy slab, or use the hand line to gain the upper alcove.   White Soul Power and Pain Drops share the same start.  Move straight up and out the closely spaced bolt line past some awesome huecos on the left edge of the steepest part of the alcove.

content.description: This is a high quality line!  Perfect stone, interesting sequences, and sustained.   Shared start with Vision Seeker.  Follow obvious huecos to the 5th bolt.   From here, follow the bolt line that heads straight up, next 2 bolts being the crux.  Aim for a nice pod and a shake before a nice technical face on solution pockets to the chains.
content.location: Between Secrets and Lies, 11a and Heart and Soul, 13b.  White rock with lots of huecos.

content.description: A thin, tricky start through less-featured, smoother limestone with small pockets and small edges leads to steeper rock and bigger holds above. Exciting, strenuous liebacking along flake edges awaits, with the final move to the chains on welcome, slightly less steep terrain.
content.protection: 8 bolts to an odd anchor: one chain with a quicklink above a hanger with a steel, hardware-store carabiner.
content.location:
On the far right of the right-side alcove of

The Arch Wall

. The first bolt hanger is bright, and the line of bolts skirts the left side of a large bulge and then the left side of a smaller bulge/roof above. The anchor is hard to recognize from the ground because of its unusual configuration.

There are a number of hanger-less studs sticking out among the line's bolts.

content.description: Superb pockets, edges and rock on this one.
content.location: Near the apex of the slope, find a hand line 25' below a steep alcove.  Climb up the easy slab, or use the hand line to gain the upper alcove.   Lost Soul begins about 10' left of the comfortable belay stance below W.S.P.

content.description: Trending slightly right, bear hug your way past the barrel in the steeper part of cave past eight bolts to anchor.
content.location: Near the apex of the slope, find a hand line 25' below a steep alcove.  Climb up the easy slab, or use the hand line to gain the upper alcove.  Flesh and Blood climbs out the steepest part of the alcove beginning just a few feet right of W.S.P.

content.description: Really fun, relatively long route. Similar to Righteous Indignation but with a slightly harder crux coming in the last couple moves.
content.location: The second route on the left side of the Arch Wall, just a few feet uphill from Righteous Indignation

content.description:
An exciting line up the overhanging right side of a limestone rib. Follow positive pockets and huge jugs for a couple of bolts, followed by less-obvious holds (and a couple of two finger pockets), to sidepulls and footholds a little closer to the overhang than seems comfortable.

After the fifth bolt the angle eases considerably and it's slabby, sharp-edge climbing up and left to the anchors.
content.location:
Travels the right side of the rib separating the two steep, overhanging cave-ish areas of

The Arch Wall

. Shares the last bolt and anchors with a line that climbs the lower-angled part of the same rib:

Wendigo

, 5.8.

content.description:
Arch Rival

is a long and epic tear up the center region of the

Arch Wall

.

Arch Rival

starts out on a slab with pockets and finger buckets and gradually gets steeper and deeper leading you through two large huecos. Don't fall victim to the funky, off-balance moves, you'll need your head for the final dash to the chains.
content.protection: Ten bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
Arch Rival

sits beneath a small limestone arch. It is easily recognized by a line of bolts running directly through two large, dark huecos.

content.description:
Arch Enemy

is an enhanced verion of

Arch Rival

. Starting out on a more demanding, intense slab,

Arch Enemy

climbs through low angle terrain via shallow pockets to a steep head wall. Be quick while firing through this bulge or the pump will sneak up, hold on tight and dig deep, perseverance can be a wonderful thing. Catch a good rest after the crux and tip toe to the chains.
content.protection: 12 bolts to hangers. Mussy hooks on the anchor.
content.location:
Arch Enemy

is the middle route below the wall's only arch. It is also the first, left most route to ascend the steep and colorful upper face.
